Serious question: at which point do we all, as an industry, finally agree that no Internet-facing middlebox that aggregates and intermediates SSL/TLS traffic is an acceptable approach to implementing a security capability?

While I'm ranting about Secure by Design, I'll also say that it should be clear that it requires context on how the product is designed and built in order to have security-informed design. It's not achieved by context-free approaches like source code scanning, blind fuzzing, etc.

The V8 Sandbox is an example of what I'd call SxD:

https://t.co/imJzMxMZk2

It takes real attacks and threat model into account, explains why rewriting in Rust, memory tagging aren't enough.

Generic secure development and mitigations are great, but alone not sufficient for SxD.
